elements.content: Micro-/nanocapsules have received substantial attention due to various potential applications for storage, catalysis, and drug delivery. However, their conventional enclosed non-/polycrystalline walls pose huge obstacles for rapid loading and mass diffusion. Here, we present a new single-crystal capsular-MOF with openings on the wall, which is carefully designed at the molecular level and constructed from a crystal-structure transformation. This rare open-capsule MOF can easily load the largest amounts of sulfur and iodine among known MOFs. In addition, derived from capsular-MOF and melamine through pyrolysis–phosphidation, we fabricated a nitrogen-doped capsular carbon-based framework with iron–nickel phosphide nanoparticles immobilized on capsular carbons interconnected by plentiful carbon nanotubes. Benefiting from synergistic effects between the carbon framework and highly surface-exposed phosphide sites, the material exhibits efficient multifunctional electrocatalysis for oxygen evolution, hydrogen evolution, and oxygen reduction, achieving well-qualified assemblies of an overall water splitting (low potential of 1.59 V at 10 mA·cm–2) and a rechargeable Zn–air battery (high peak power density of 250 mW·cm–2 and excellent stability for 500 h), which afford remarkably practical prospects over previously known electrocatalysts.

In addition, derived from capsular-MOF and melamine through pyrolysis-phosphidation, we fabricated a nitrogen-doped capsular carbon-based framework with iron-nickel phosphide nanoparticles immobilized on capsular carbons interconnected by plentiful carbon nanotubes. Benefiting from synergistic effects between the carbon framework and highly surface-exposed phosphide sites, the material exhibits efficient multifunctional electrocatalysis for oxygen evolution, hydrogen evolution, and oxygen reduction, achieving well-qualified assemblies of an overall water splitting (low potential of 1.59 V at 10 mA⋅cm-2) and a rechargeable Zn-air battery (high peak power density of 250 mW⋅cm-2 and excellent stability for 500 h), which afford remarkably practical prospects over previously known electrocatalysts.

elements.content: Micro-/nanocapsules have gained considerable attention in various promising fields including storage/encapsulation, catalysis, and drug delivery by virtue of their high exposed surface, modifiable shell, and large accommodation space. However, to our knowledge, most of the capsules have enclosed structures, which would seriously hinder mass diffusion and exposure of inner surfaces. Thus, designing and constructing new capsules with openings is highly desired but rarely reported so far. In this context, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), constructed by metal ions and organic ligands, have shown great potential in the synthesis of capsular crystals, which are generally prepared by prefabricating a core–shell intermediate with an inactive solid as inner template. Nevertheless, this method usually suffers from their complicated time-consuming processes and harsh conditions of template removal. Recently, self-templated strategies that do not require removal of the cores have been developed to prepare hollow MOF crystals, while most of them afford undesired polycrystalline hollows close-packed by small MOF crystals with enclosed morphologies. It is a big challenge to rationally design and construct capsular MOF nanocrystals with openings on the wall, let alone present single crystallinity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Micro-/nanocapsules have gained considerable attention in various promising fields including storage/encapsulation, catalysis, and drug delivery by virtue of their high exposed surface, modifiable shell, and large accommodation space. However, to our knowledge, most of the capsules have enclosed structures, which would seriously hinder mass diffusion and exposure of inner surfaces. Thus, designing and constructing new capsules with openings is highly desired but rarely reported so far. In this context, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), constructed by metal ions and organic ligands, have shown great potential in the synthesis of capsular crystals, which are generally prepared by prefabricating a core-shell intermediate with an inactive solid as inner template. Nevertheless, this method usually suffers from their complicated time-consuming processes and harsh conditions of template removal. Recently, self-templated strategies that do not require removal of the cores have been developed to prepare hollow MOF crystals, while most of them afford undesired polycrystalline hollows close-packed by small MOF crystals with enclosed morphologies. It is a big challenge to rationally design and construct capsular MOF nanocrystals with openings on the wall, let alone present single crystallinity.

elements.content: Kinetic control of MOF crystal recrystallization (dissolution–regrowth) has a significant effect on crystal engineering and morphology. Especially when the structures of parent and shell crystals are well-matched, shell crystals will uniformly grow on outer surfaces of parent crystals, the cores of which simultaneously dissolve and diffuse out. In other words, this core-to-surface mass transfer will probably lead to the formation of single-crystal capsular structures and leave plentiful openings on the wall, although the shape-controlled regrowth of single-crystal capsular MOFs from crystal-structure transformations are rarely achieved.
elements.clean_text: Kinetic control of MOF crystal recrystallization (dissolution-regrowth) has a significant effect on crystal engineering and morphology. Especially when the structures of parent and shell crystals are well-matched, shell crystals will uniformly grow on outer surfaces of parent crystals, the cores of which simultaneously dissolve and diffuse out. In other words, this core-to-surface mass transfer will probably lead to the formation of single-crystal capsular structures and leave plentiful openings on the wall, although the shape-controlled regrowth of single-crystal capsular MOFs from crystal-structure transformations are rarely achieved.

elements.content: Herein, we developed a self-templated strategy to successfully construct an iron–nickel-based single-crystal open capsular-MOF, which is carefully designed and constructed from crystal-structure transformations at the molecular level. This rare open-capsule MOF can easily encapsulate sulfur and iodine with the highest capacities among known MOFs. Moreover, through pyrolysis–phosphidation with melamine, capsular nanocrystals can evolve into a nitrogen-doped carbon hollow (NCH) framework with iron–nickel phosphide (FeNiP) nanoparticles embedded in open capsular carbons interconnected by plentiful carbon nanotubes (FeNiP/NCH). Coupled with its superior electrocatalysis for oxygen evolution, hydrogen evolution, and oxygen reduction, we successfully use FeNiP/NCH as the only electrocatalyst to multifunctionally assemble an overall water splitting (low potential of 1.59 V at 10 mA·cm–2) and a rechargeable Zn–air battery (high peak power density of 250 mW·cm–2 and excellent stability for 500 h). As far as we know, this is the first design and construction of an open-capsule nanostructure that offers excellent material encapsulation and multicatalytic performances with greatly potential applications in practice.

Moreover, through pyrolysis-phosphidation with melamine, capsular nanocrystals can evolve into a nitrogen-doped carbon hollow (NCH) framework with iron-nickel phosphide (FeNiP) nanoparticles embedded in open capsular carbons interconnected by plentiful carbon nanotubes (FeNiP/NCH). Coupled with its superior electrocatalysis for oxygen evolution, hydrogen evolution, and oxygen reduction, we successfully use FeNiP/NCH as the only electrocatalyst to multifunctionally assemble an overall water splitting (low potential of 1.59 V at 10 mA⋅cm-2) and a rechargeable Zn-air battery (high peak power density of 250 mW⋅cm-2 and excellent stability for 500 h). As far as we know, this is the first design and construction of an open-capsule nanostructure that offers excellent material encapsulation and multicatalytic performances with greatly potential applications in practice.

elements.content: With addition of ligand 2,4,6-tris­(4-pyridyl)­pyridine (tpy), uniform capsular-MOF nanocrystals (elongated hexagonal dipyramid) can be facilely prepared by using nonhollow crystals of FeNi-MIL-88B as the template in hot N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (a, S1, and S2). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) reveal, unlike the nonhollow nanocrystals of FeNi-MIL-88B (b, S3, and S4), an extremely rare capsular morphology with openings on the wall (c, S5, and S6). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) maps show its uniform distribution of iron and nickel (d and S7). Surprisingly, the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern reveals that the open capsular-MOFs are single crystals (e). Compared with FeNi-MIL-88B (P63/mmc, a = 12.8849(9) Å, c = 18.3064(2) Å, V = 2632.1(4) Å3, Figures S8 and S9), capsular-MOF shows a distinctly different powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern, which can be well indexed in the same space group by Pawley refinement (Figure S8). Its derived unit-cell parameters vary greatly (a = 16.8736(9) Å, c = 14.8709(7) Å, V = 3666.8(5) Å3, Figure S10 and Table S1), implying that tpy may successfully participate in constructing the capsular structure in combination with the results of infrared spectroscopy (IR) (Figures S11 and S12). For comparison, a conventional synthesis gives solid-MOF (nonhollow MOF) nanocrystals by directly using the same starting materials. A series of characterizations including PXRD, IR, SEM, and TEM shows that solid-MOF is isostructural to capsular-MOF (Figures S2, S8, S10, S12, and S13 and Table S1) but has a different uniform crystal external shape (fat hexagonal dipyramid) (Figures S2, S14, and S15), indicating that the capsular-MOF should grow from the parent crystal (FeNi-MIL-88B). In particular, capsular-MOF and solid-MOF present identical Type-I N2 adsorption isotherms and pore size distributions (f) with corresponding Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of 1157 and 1010 m2 g–1 and pore volumes of 0.728 and 0.558 cm3 g–1, respectively (Table S2). Notably, a remarkable desorption hysteresis loop was solely observed in capsular-MOF, sufficiently indicating the mesostructured voids caused by the capsular nanostructure. In contrast, guest-free FeNi-MIL-88B showed a type-II isotherm with a negligible uptake because its shrunken framework is hardly opened by nitrogen molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Fabrication of Open Capsular-MOF Nanocrystals and Encapsulation of Sulfur and Iodine

With addition of ligand 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)pyridine (tpy), uniform capsular-MOF nanocrystals (elongated hexagonal dipyramid) can be facilely prepared by using nonhollow crystals of FeNi-MIL-88B as the template in hot N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (a, S1, and S2). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) reveal, unlike the nonhollow nanocrystals of FeNi-MIL-88B (b, S3, and S4), an extremely rare capsular morphology with openings on the wall (c, S5, and S6). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) maps show its uniform distribution of iron and nickel (d and S7). Surprisingly, the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern reveals that the open capsular-MOFs are single crystals (e). Compared with FeNi-MIL-88B (P63/mmc, a = 12.8849(9) Å, c = 18.3064(2) Å, V = 2632.1(4) Å3, Figures S8 and S9), capsular-MOF shows a distinctly different powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern, which can be well indexed in the same space group by Pawley refinement (Figure S8). Its derived unit-cell parameters vary greatly (a = 16.8736(9) Å, c = 14.8709(7) Å, V = 3666.8(5) Å3, Figure S10 and Table S1), implying that tpy may successfully participate in constructing the capsular structure in combination with the results of infrared spectroscopy (IR) (Figures S11 and S12). For comparison, a conventional synthesis gives solid-MOF (nonhollow MOF) nanocrystals by directly using the same starting materials. A series of characterizations including PXRD, IR, SEM, and TEM shows that solid-MOF is isostructural to capsular-MOF (Figures S2, S8, S10, S12, and S13 and Table S1) but has a different uniform crystal external shape (fat hexagonal dipyramid) (Figures S2, S14, and S15), indicating that the capsular-MOF should grow from the parent crystal (FeNi-MIL-88B). In particular, capsular-MOF and solid-MOF present identical Type-I N2 adsorption isotherms and pore size distributions (f) with corresponding Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of 1157 and 1010 m2 g-1 and pore volumes of 0.728 and 0.558 cm3 g-1, respectively (Table S2). Notably, a remarkable desorption hysteresis loop was solely observed in capsular-MOF, sufficiently indicating the mesostructured voids caused by the capsular nanostructure. In contrast, guest-free FeNi-MIL-88B showed a type-II isotherm with a negligible uptake because its shrunken framework is hardly opened by nitrogen molecules.

elements.content: To reveal structural details for the growth mechanism of the open capsule, we carried out successive characterizations for time-dependent intermediates every 2 h during synthesis of capsular-MOF, including PXRD, BET surface areas, SEM, and TEM. PXRD analyses (Figure S16a) confirm that the crystals at the fourth hour possess mixed crystal structures of FeNi-MIL-88B and capsular-MOF, indicating that the crystal of FeNi-MIL-88B was partially transformed into capsular-MOF, which was verified by an obvious increase in BET surface area (Figure S16b and Table S3). Further increasing the reaction time resulted in unchanged PXRD patterns and N2 adsorption isotherms. Nevertheless, the desorption hysteresis loop gradually became larger and larger, implying the growth of capsular nanostructures. SEM and TEM images at the fourth hour revealed plenty of concave defects on all crystal faces of parent FeNi-MIL-88B crystals, which can undergo severe surface etches and release Fe3+, Ni2+, and bdc-NH2 2– into the solution (Figures S17 and S18). When the sixth hour was reached, the ravined surface of the crystals was partially refilled, indicating that the crystal surface may be constructed by Fe3+, Ni2+, bdc-NH2 2–, and tpy from the solution. As time goes on (the eighth through twelfth hour), the shape of overall crystal changed slightly, while the inner core of crystal was seemingly dissolved to release metal ions and ligands into the solution mainly through openings on the walls. Obviously, the origination of openings should come from some big early formed concave defects on the parent crystals. In addition, as shown in Figures S17, the density of openings in the nanocrystal walls decreases with increasing the reaction time.

elements.content: To understand more details at the molecular level for capsular growth, we also carried out single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) analyses. In order to obtain crystals suitable for SCXRD and for the convenience of subsequent analysis, we used only FeCl3 and H2bdc-NH2 with/without tpy to successfully synthesize large crystals of Fe-MIL-88B-tpy/Fe-MIL-88B. As expected, the unit-cell parameters of Fe-MIL-88B-tpy and Fe-MIL-88B are almost identical to those obtained from capsular-MOF and FeNi-MIL-88B with small differences of the axes (<0.3%), respectively, manifesting that they are isostructural MOFs (Tables S1 and S4). Careful structural analysis of Fe-MIL-88B-tpy supports that, besides the 6-connected acs networks similar to that of Fe-MIL-88B, each tpy ligand coordinates with the three Fe­(III) ions by its three pyridyl ends, giving a rigid framework (g,h and S19). In particular, the electron-density distribution of tpy can be clearly observed in the X-ray difference Fourier maps (i,j and S20). In other words, when tpy is ignored, capsular-MOF actually has an isoreticular backbone with FeNi-MIL-88B. It should be noted that the capsular structure cannot be constructed via similar treatment of Fe-MIL-88B with tpy (Figures S21 and S22). Coupled with the fact that introduction of additional size-matching ligands into MOFs can drastically enhance the structural stabilities, a dissolution-regrowth mechanism for capsular-MOF is naturally proposed. That is, in hot DMF, crystal faces of parent FeNi-MIL-88B crystals first undergo severe surface etches by the hot solution and tpy is anchored on the uncoordinated Fe­(III)/Ni­(II) sites of the parent crystal surface. Then the inner core of the crystal is simultaneously dissolved to release Fe3+, Ni2+, and bdc-NH2 2– into the solution. Considering the identical orientations of crystal faces calculated from relevant single-crystal structures (Figure S23), these released ions will diffuse out of the crystal through these openings and then directly participate in constructing the new structure with tpy on the parent crystal surface. After that, the outer layer continues to grow with dissolution of the inner core, finally generating well-defined capsular nanocrystals with openings on the wall (Figure S24).

elements.content: Within this context, this capsular-MOF with openings on the wall therefore attracts considerable interests because of its great promising application in storage. To address this issue, we use capsular-MOF to store sulfur (S) and iodine (I2) (), both of which have been exploited as new-type cathodes for rechargeable lithium–sulfur/iodine batteries with high theoretical energy density/discharge capacities. It is believed that the higher loadings of S and I2 will greatly enhance the battery performances. Sulfur and iodine were introduced into the MOF capsules through melt-diffusion and I2 vapor adsorption methods, respectively (a and S25). After loading, the color of I2@capsular-MOF changed apparently from gray to brown (black for solid-MOF), while the S@MOF remains almost unchanged (b and S26). Furthermore, both their original morphologies and crystallinities of these MOFs were well-maintained as evidenced by SEM and PXRD patterns, respectively (c and S27–30). The successful loadings of sulfur and iodine into the micropore of the single-crystalline wall were distinctly reflected in the drastic decrease in N2 uptakes of these samples with maximum permitted loads in comparison to the pristine MOFs (d and S31). Their exact loadings were analyzed quantitatively by thermal-gravimetric analysis (TGA) (e and S32). As expected, capsular-MOF represents the highest loadings of 2.00 g/g for sulfur and 2.57g/g for iodine among all known MOFs including the solid-MOF (0.72 and 1.38 g/g, respectively) (f and Tables S5 and S6). Considering that nonhollow MOF crystals are hard to be fully filled by S and I2 molecules in a short time, we believe the unique openings on the wall provide a shortcut to the inner surface of capsular MOF, thus effectively enhancing the mass transfer and storage.

elements.content: Recently, MOF-derived carbon composites, possessing excellent chemical stabilities and conductivities, have shown great potential applications in energy storage and conversion. However, nonhollow MOF-derived nanocomposites usually exhibit complete microporosity and undesired aggregation of metal-based nanoparticles, which are considered unfavorable for ion and electron transport. On the basis of these concerns, hollow architectures have recently emerged as an effective platform to significantly improve catalytic efficiency of metal nanocomposites because their shell nanostructures can endow materials with a higher density of surface-exposed active sites. More importantly, compared with those widely reported nonhollow MOF crystal-derived hollow carbons, directly using hollow MOF crystals as precursors can effectively reduce the aggregation of metal active sites during pyrolysis, although harsh annealing usually causes a partial or even complete collapse of MOF morphologies. Fortunately, through pyrolysis–phosphidation with melamine, capsular-MOF successfully evolved into a capsular carbon embedded with iron–nickel phosphide nanoparticles ( and S33). For comparison, FeNiP/NCS from solid (nonhollow)-MOF and FeNiP/C from FeNi-MIL-88B were also prepared. PXRD of FeNiP/NCH shows a weak peak located at 26.4° assigned to the (002) plane of graphitic carbon (b), which is further verified by the IR and Raman spectra with a G-band at 1586 cm–1 (Figure S34). Besides, the D-band of Raman spectra at 1355 cm–1 manifests the presence of a disordered/defect carbon. Additionally, other peaks appearing at 32.2, 36.8, 48.0, and 56.1° can be indexed to (−202), (021), (220), and (310) planes of NiP2, and peaks at 31.2, 35.2, 40.2, 44.1, and 47.6° refer to (101), (200), (111), (201), and (210) planes of Fe2P, respectively. Remarkably, all of the diffraction peaks are significantly broadened, which might be due to ultrafine sizes of NiP2 and Fe2P nanoparticles confirmed by subsequent TEM and SAED measurements. However, for FeNiP/C and FeNiP/NCS, these peaks become more sharp, and nonphosphatized Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloys (PDF no. 47-1405) are obviously observed (Figure S35). SEM and TEM images demonstrate that FeNiP/NCH retains capsular morphology with larger openings compared with capsular-MOF (c,d). As a secondary nitrogen and carbon source, coexistence of melamine results in the growth of numerous carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on the surface of capsular carbons, which are successfully connected with each other to form networks (Figures S36 and S37). HRTEM, SAED, and HAADF-STEM images and elemental maps of FeNiP/NCH (f, S37, and S38) reveal that Fe, Ni, and P elements are uniformly distributed over the entire capsule. Obviously, by virtue of spatially homogeneous separation of Fe­(III) and Ni­(II) ions in the thin walls of precursor capsular nanocrystals, the NiP2 and Fe2P nanoparticles are homogeneously distributed over the entire capsule nanostructures with extremely small sizes. Compared with FeNiP/NCH, as suggested by PXRD and SAED, besides larger nanoparticles of NiP2 and Fe2P, Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloy is found in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C (Figures S39–S43), which can be possibly attributed to the partial phosphorization of large nanoparticles of Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloy in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C. Their chemical status and elemental composition are further studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) analysis. A survey scan of FeNiP/NCH reveals the presence of C, O, N, P, Fe, and Ni (Figure S44). The high-resolution spectrum of N 1s can be divided into three peaks at 400.9, 399.9, and 398.7 eV, corresponding to graphitic, pyrrolic, and pyridinic-N, respectively. Significantly, the signal peak of P 2p (133.5 eV) can be definitely detected, and similar results are obtained in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C, demonstrating their successful phosphorization (Figure S45). Notably, only in XPS of FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C, signal peaks of metallic Fe 2p3/2 (707.0 eV) and Ni 2p3/2 (852.7 eV) can be detected (Figure S46), in good agreement with PXRD, HRTEM, and SAED. N2 sorption measurements reveal that FeNiP/NCH shows a high BET surface area of 142 m2·g–1 and pore volume of 0.549 cm3·g–1, larger than those of FeNiP/NCS (118 m2·g–1, 0.367 cm3·g–1) and FeNiP/C (79 m2·g–1, 0.226 cm3·g–1) (Figure S47a and Table S2). Pore size distribution curves (Figure S47b) illustrate that FeNiP/NCH possesses obviously mesoporous structures (∼10 nm). Moreover, as also suggested by TEM (d, S37, S41, and S42), FeNiP/NCH, FeNiP/NCS, and FeNiP/C have rich macropores. These unique hierarchical pores will be significantly beneficial to mass and charge transport for electrocatalysis.

Preparation of Capsular Carbon-Based Network Derived from the Open Capsular-MOF

Recently, MOF-derived carbon composites, possessing excellent chemical stabilities and conductivities, have shown great potential applications in energy storage and conversion. However, nonhollow MOF-derived nanocomposites usually exhibit complete microporosity and undesired aggregation of metal-based nanoparticles, which are considered unfavorable for ion and electron transport. On the basis of these concerns, hollow architectures have recently emerged as an effective platform to significantly improve catalytic efficiency of metal nanocomposites because their shell nanostructures can endow materials with a higher density of surface-exposed active sites. More importantly, compared with those widely reported nonhollow MOF crystal-derived hollow carbons, directly using hollow MOF crystals as precursors can effectively reduce the aggregation of metal active sites during pyrolysis, although harsh annealing usually causes a partial or even complete collapse of MOF morphologies. Fortunately, through pyrolysis-phosphidation with melamine, capsular-MOF successfully evolved into a capsular carbon embedded with iron-nickel phosphide nanoparticles ( and S33). For comparison, FeNiP/NCS from solid (nonhollow)-MOF and FeNiP/C from FeNi-MIL-88B were also prepared. PXRD of FeNiP/NCH shows a weak peak located at 26.4° assigned to the (002) plane of graphitic carbon (b), which is further verified by the IR and Raman spectra with a G-band at 1586 cm-1 (Figure S34). Besides, the D-band of Raman spectra at 1355 cm-1 manifests the presence of a disordered/defect carbon. Additionally, other peaks appearing at 32.2, 36.8, 48.0, and 56.1° can be indexed to (-202), (021), (220), and (310) planes of NiP2, and peaks at 31.2, 35.2, 40.2, 44.1, and 47.6° refer to (101), (200), (111), (201), and (210) planes of Fe2P, respectively. Remarkably, all of the diffraction peaks are significantly broadened, which might be due to ultrafine sizes of NiP2 and Fe2P nanoparticles confirmed by subsequent TEM and SAED measurements. However, for FeNiP/C and FeNiP/NCS, these peaks become more sharp, and nonphosphatized Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloys (PDF no. 47-1405) are obviously observed (Figure S35). SEM and TEM images demonstrate that FeNiP/NCH retains capsular morphology with larger openings compared with capsular-MOF (c,d). As a secondary nitrogen and carbon source, coexistence of melamine results in the growth of numerous carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on the surface of capsular carbons, which are successfully connected with each other to form networks (Figures S36 and S37). HRTEM, SAED, and HAADF-STEM images and elemental maps of FeNiP/NCH (f, S37, and S38) reveal that Fe, Ni, and P elements are uniformly distributed over the entire capsule. Obviously, by virtue of spatially homogeneous separation of Fe(III) and Ni(II) ions in the thin walls of precursor capsular nanocrystals, the NiP2 and Fe2P nanoparticles are homogeneously distributed over the entire capsule nanostructures with extremely small sizes. Compared with FeNiP/NCH, as suggested by PXRD and SAED, besides larger nanoparticles of NiP2 and Fe2P, Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloy is found in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C (Figures S39-S43), which can be possibly attributed to the partial phosphorization of large nanoparticles of Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloy in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C. Their chemical status and elemental composition are further studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) analysis. A survey scan of FeNiP/NCH reveals the presence of C, O, N, P, Fe, and Ni (Figure S44). The high-resolution spectrum of N 1s can be divided into three peaks at 400.9, 399.9, and 398.7 eV, corresponding to graphitic, pyrrolic, and pyridinic-N, respectively. Significantly, the signal peak of P 2p (133.5 eV) can be definitely detected, and similar results are obtained in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C, demonstrating their successful phosphorization (Figure S45). Notably, only in XPS of FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C, signal peaks of metallic Fe 2p3/2 (707.0 eV) and Ni 2p3/2 (852.7 eV) can be detected (Figure S46), in good agreement with PXRD, HRTEM, and SAED. N2 sorption measurements reveal that FeNiP/NCH shows a high BET surface area of 142 m2⋅g-1 and pore volume of 0.549 cm3⋅g-1, larger than those of FeNiP/NCS (118 m2⋅g-1, 0.367 cm3⋅g-1) and FeNiP/C (79 m2⋅g-1, 0.226 cm3⋅g-1) (Figure S47a and Table S2). Pore size distribution curves (Figure S47b) illustrate that FeNiP/NCH possesses obviously mesoporous structures (~10 nm). Moreover, as also suggested by TEM (d, S37, S41, and S42), FeNiP/NCH, FeNiP/NCS, and FeNiP/C have rich macropores. These unique hierarchical pores will be significantly beneficial to mass and charge transport for electrocatalysis.

elements.content: The above combined analytical measurements show that FeNiP/NCH possesses a capsular carbon-based framework and abundant Fe2P and NiP2 nanoparticles, making it a promising electrocatalyst for oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which serves as an essential reaction for water electrolysis devices and rechargeable metal-air batteries technologies. As shown in a, FeNiP/NCH exhibits the lowest overpotential of 250 mV at 10 mA cm–2, superior to those of FeNiP/C (293 mV), FeNiP/NCS (314 mV), IrO2 (387 mV), and even among all reported non-noble metal phosphide catalysts on GCE (glassy carbon electrode) (Figures S48 and S49 and Tables S7 and S8). Additionally, the Tafel slope (68 mV dec–1) of FeNiP/NCH is smaller than those of FeNiP/C (89 mV dec–1) FeNiP/NCS (107 mV dec–1) and IrO2 (117 mV dec–1), signifying its superior reaction kinetics (b). Furthermore, the FeNi/NCH offers active sites 1.8 and 1.9 times that of FeNiP/C and FeNiP/NCS, respectively, and accordingly, the TOF of FeNiP/NCH (0.25 s–1 at 1.53 V) is remarkably larger than those of FeNiP/C (0.15 s–1) and FeNiP/NCS (0.084 s–1) (Figure S50 and Table S9), which is almost the lowest value reported for bimetallic (phosphides) catalysts, only behind one known NiCo-MOF nanosheet electrocatalyst (Figures S48 and S49 and Tables S7 and S8).

Oxygen Evolution Reaction

The above combined analytical measurements show that FeNiP/NCH possesses a capsular carbon-based framework and abundant Fe2P and NiP2 nanoparticles, making it a promising electrocatalyst for oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which serves as an essential reaction for water electrolysis devices and rechargeable metal-air batteries technologies. As shown in a, FeNiP/NCH exhibits the lowest overpotential of 250 mV at 10 mA cm-2, superior to those of FeNiP/C (293 mV), FeNiP/NCS (314 mV), IrO2 (387 mV), and even among all reported non-noble metal phosphide catalysts on GCE (glassy carbon electrode) (Figures S48 and S49 and Tables S7 and S8). Additionally, the Tafel slope (68 mV dec-1) of FeNiP/NCH is smaller than those of FeNiP/C (89 mV dec-1) FeNiP/NCS (107 mV dec-1) and IrO2 (117 mV dec-1), signifying its superior reaction kinetics (b). Furthermore, the FeNi/NCH offers active sites 1.8 and 1.9 times that of FeNiP/C and FeNiP/NCS, respectively, and accordingly, the TOF of FeNiP/NCH (0.25 s-1 at 1.53 V) is remarkably larger than those of FeNiP/C (0.15 s-1) and FeNiP/NCS (0.084 s-1) (Figure S50 and Table S9), which is almost the lowest value reported for bimetallic (phosphides) catalysts, only behind one known NiCo-MOF nanosheet electrocatalyst (Figures S48 and S49 and Tables S7 and S8).

elements.content: To ensure that the observed oxidation current was really from oxygen evolution, we used a rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) method to detect electron-transfer numbers and Faradaic efficiency during OER processes. First, when oxygen generated on the disk electrode and the Pt ring electrode was held at the peroxide oxidation potential of 1.50 V, a negligible current was detected on the Pt ring (μA scale) (Figure S51), which is 3 orders of magnitude lower than the disk current (mA scale), indicating no production of peroxide. Then the associated Faradaic efficiency was investigated by maintaining a ring potential of 0.4 V for continuous reduction of oxygen molecules generated and diffused from the disk electrode. As a result, when a constant disk current (325 μA) was applied for OER, a ring current of ∼68 μA was detected (collection efficiency 0.42) (c), which actually verified that the observed catalytic current of FeNiP/NCH originated exclusively from OER with a high Faradaic efficiency of 99.5%.

First, when oxygen generated on the disk electrode and the Pt ring electrode was held at the peroxide oxidation potential of 1.50 V, a negligible current was detected on the Pt ring (μA scale) (Figure S51), which is 3 orders of magnitude lower than the disk current (mA scale), indicating no production of peroxide. Then the associated Faradaic efficiency was investigated by maintaining a ring potential of 0.4 V for continuous reduction of oxygen molecules generated and diffused from the disk electrode. As a result, when a constant disk current (325 μA) was applied for OER, a ring current of ~68 μA was detected (collection efficiency 0.42) (c), which actually verified that the observed catalytic current of FeNiP/NCH originated exclusively from OER with a high Faradaic efficiency of 99.5%.

elements.content: Strong durability for electrocatalysts is of great importance for energy conversion and storage systems. As depicted in the inset of d, a negligible decay can be observed by comparing the LSV curves before and after 5000 cycles. Subsequently, its catalytic activities could be well-retained for another 72 h (d). To determine the possible origins of such an extraordinary performance, it is essential to further elucidate structure and chemical composition for post-OER sample. As shown in Figure S52, the morphology of FeNiP/NCH basically remains after the OER test. PXRD confirms that a mixture of iron oxyhydroxides (FeOOH) and nickel hydroxide hydrate (Ni­(OH)2·2/3H2O) evolves from Fe2P and NiP2 after OER testing, respectively (a), which are verified by XPS analysis, judging from the disappearance of P and reservation of Fe and Ni signals (Figure S53). Considering that iron oxyhydroxides and nickel hydroxide hydrate should be simultaneously in situ generated from the mixture of Fe2P and NiP2, hybridization with each other at a trace amount level is hardly avoided as reported previously. As a result, these introduced impurities have been experimentally proven to greatly boost the catalytic activity, which is responsible for the superior catalytic performance toward water oxidation.

elements.content: In addition, the electrochemically active surface area is another important contributor to facilitate the catalytic activity of OER catalysts. Thus, the electrochemical surface areas (ECSAs) of FeNiP/NCH catalyst were investigated by measuring the double-layer capacitance (C dl) (Figure S54). The C dl of FeNiP/NCH catalyst (8.1 mF·cm–2) is much higher than those of the FeNiP/C (5.0 mF cm–2) and FeNiP/NCS (3.6 mF cm–2), suggesting that FeNiP/NCH has the largest ECSA among these materials (Figure S54e). The lower charge-transfer resistance (R ct, 1.174 Ω) of FeNiP/NCH compared to 2.829 Ω of FeNiP/C and 3.225 Ω of FeNiP/NCS also suggests that its unique capsular carbon networks effectively reduce ionic transport resistance and significantly facilitate the kinetic electron transfer under OER operations (Table S10). In brief, such an outstanding catalytic performance of FeNiP/NCH should be attributed to its unique capsular carbon-based network nanostructure, which endows the material with a highly electrochemically active surface area and efficient electron/charge transfer from the electrode.

elements.content: Motivated by the outstanding OER performance of FeNiP/NCH, electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) was also investigated. Distinctly, FeNiP/NCH obtains 10 mA cm–2 at a small overpotential of 216 mV, which is superior to the FeNiP/C (258 mV) and FeNiP/NCS (315 mV) catalysts. The corresponding Tafel slope of the FeNiP/NCH catalyst (125 mV dec–1) is also smaller than those of FeNiP/C (144 mV dec–1), FeNiP/NCS (177 mV dec–1) (a), and many other reported bifunctional catalysts (Table S11), revealing more favorable electrocatalytic kinetics on the FeNiP/NCH catalyst for HER. It should be noted that the Tafel slope of FeNiP/NCH catalyst (125 mV dec–1) suggests that its HER process undergoes a Volmer–Heyrovesky pathway. Notably, LSV scanning for 5000 cycles and long-term chronoamperometry (>68 h) measurements demonstrate its good stability during HER (Figures S55 and S56). Moreover, the structure and chemical components of FeNiP/NCH can be preserved very well after HER tests (Figures S57 and S58). Considering the electrocatalytic activities of FeNiP/NCH for HER and OER with excellent stabilities, an electrolyzer was assembled using FeNiP/NCH as both cathode and anode for overall water splitting. As revealed in LSV (b and S59), FeNiP/NCH exhibits outstanding splitting performance with a small cell voltage of 1.59 and 1.91 V to achieve 10 and 100 mA cm–2, respectively, superior to those of many reported non-noble-metal electrocatalysts (Table S12). In addition, the water electrolyzer durability was well confirmed by carrying out the reaction at different current densities from 10 to 100 mA cm–2 for over 40 h (c and S60), proving the prominent stability of FeNiP/NCH catalyst for overall water splitting.

Hydrogen Evolution and Overall Water Splitting

Motivated by the outstanding OER performance of FeNiP/NCH, electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) was also investigated. Distinctly, FeNiP/NCH obtains 10 mA cm-2 at a small overpotential of 216 mV, which is superior to the FeNiP/C (258 mV) and FeNiP/NCS (315 mV) catalysts. The corresponding Tafel slope of the FeNiP/NCH catalyst (125 mV dec-1) is also smaller than those of FeNiP/C (144 mV dec-1), FeNiP/NCS (177 mV dec-1) (a), and many other reported bifunctional catalysts (Table S11), revealing more favorable electrocatalytic kinetics on the FeNiP/NCH catalyst for HER. It should be noted that the Tafel slope of FeNiP/NCH catalyst (125 mV dec-1) suggests that its HER process undergoes a Volmer-Heyrovesky pathway. Notably, LSV scanning for 5000 cycles and long-term chronoamperometry (>68 h) measurements demonstrate its good stability during HER (Figures S55 and S56). Moreover, the structure and chemical components of FeNiP/NCH can be preserved very well after HER tests (Figures S57 and S58). Considering the electrocatalytic activities of FeNiP/NCH for HER and OER with excellent stabilities, an electrolyzer was assembled using FeNiP/NCH as both cathode and anode for overall water splitting. As revealed in LSV (b and S59), FeNiP/NCH exhibits outstanding splitting performance with a small cell voltage of 1.59 and 1.91 V to achieve 10 and 100 mA cm-2, respectively, superior to those of many reported non-noble-metal electrocatalysts (Table S12). In addition, the water electrolyzer durability was well confirmed by carrying out the reaction at different current densities from 10 to 100 mA cm-2 for over 40 h (c and S60), proving the prominent stability of FeNiP/NCH catalyst for overall water splitting.

elements.content: The inherent high OER activity and excellent water electrolysis performance of FeNiP/NCH further prompted us to investigate its catalysis for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and even assemble it into a rechargeable Zn–air battery device to evaluate its practical application for energy conversion. As shown in the LSV curves (d), FeNiP/NCH exhibits a higher positive half-wave potential (0.75 V vs RHE, reverse hydrogen electrode) and larger diffusion-limiting current density (5.02 mA cm–2, close to that of Pt/C) than those of FeNiP/C (0.71 V, 3.22 mA cm–2) and FeNiP/NCS (0.73 V, 3.06 mA cm–2) at 0.6 V (Figures S61 and S67). Moreover, the structure and chemical components of FeNiP/NCH can also be preserved very well after ORR tests (Figures S57 and S58). In addition, the ECSAs of FeNiP/NCH catalyst in 0.1 M KOH were also investigated by C dl (Figure S68). The C dl of FeNiP/NCH catalyst (8.6 mF·cm–2) is much higher than those of the FeNiP/C (4.2 mF cm–2) and FeNiP/NCS (6.0 mF cm–2), indicating that the unique structure of FeNiP/NCH has a great influence on the electrochemically active surface areas. Actually, FeNiP/NCH can serve as one of the best ORR electrocatalysts among various metal phosphides, being comparable with other reported bi-/trifunctional catalysts (Table S12). Considering the prominent catalytic activities of FeNiP/NCH for OER and ORR, a homemade Zn–air battery is assembled to further evaluate the performance under real operation conditions (e). Entertainingly, this battery can work stably with an open-circuit voltage (OCV) of 1.48 V for more than 25 h (1.38 V for Pt/C) (Figure S69). Besides this, discharge polarization curve and peak power density of single battery clearly manifest that the FeNiP/NCH catalyst exhibits an extraordinary high power density (250 mW cm–2) that surpasses 131 mW cm–2 of Pt/C-based battery and most of other recently reported state-of-the art electrode materials (f and Table S13). The charge/discharge potentials of the Zn–air battery based on FeNiP/NCH were 1.89 and 1.23 V with a small voltage gap of 0.66 V when cycling at 5 mA cm–2, far better than the charge/discharge potentials of Pt/C (g). More significantly, it displays remarkable stability with no obvious voltage gap change over 2100 cycles during 500 h when operating at different current densities. Obviously, FeNiP/NCH performs far better than Pt/C including not only the peak power density of discharge but also the durability of operation. More impressively, two primary Zn–air batteries based on FeNiP/NCH connected in series can provide a working voltage of more than 2.95 V, which is expectedly sufficient to power the above water electrolyzer assembled by FeNiP/NCH (Figure S70).

Moreover, the structure and chemical components of FeNiP/NCH can also be preserved very well after ORR tests (Figures S57 and S58). In addition, the ECSAs of FeNiP/NCH catalyst in 0.1 M KOH were also investigated by C dl (Figure S68). The C dl of FeNiP/NCH catalyst (8.6 mF⋅cm-2) is much higher than those of the FeNiP/C (4.2 mF cm-2) and FeNiP/NCS (6.0 mF cm-2), indicating that the unique structure of FeNiP/NCH has a great influence on the electrochemically active surface areas. Actually, FeNiP/NCH can serve as one of the best ORR electrocatalysts among various metal phosphides, being comparable with other reported bi-/trifunctional catalysts (Table S12). Entertainingly, this battery can work stably with an open-circuit voltage (OCV) of 1.48 V for more than 25 h (1.38 V for Pt/C) (Figure S69). Besides this, discharge polarization curve and peak power density of single battery clearly manifest that the FeNiP/NCH catalyst exhibits an extraordinary high power density (250 mW cm-2) that surpasses 131 mW cm-2 of Pt/C-based battery and most of other recently reported state-of-the art electrode materials (f and Table S13). The charge/discharge potentials of the Zn-air battery based on FeNiP/NCH were 1.89 and 1.23 V with a small voltage gap of 0.66 V when cycling at 5 mA cm-2, far better than the charge/discharge potentials of Pt/C (g). More significantly, it displays remarkable stability with no obvious voltage gap change over 2100 cycles during 500 h when operating at different current densities. Obviously, FeNiP/NCH performs far better than Pt/C including not only the peak power density of discharge but also the durability of operation. More impressively, two primary Zn-air batteries based on FeNiP/NCH connected in series can provide a working voltage of more than 2.95 V, which is expectedly sufficient to power the above water electrolyzer assembled by FeNiP/NCH (Figure S70).

elements.content: In summary, a new single-crystal capsular-MOF with openings on the wall is carefully designed at the molecular level and constructed from a rare crystal-structure transformation from a well-known three-dimensional MOF for the first time. Interestingly, the open-capsular MOF can be used as a nanoscale storage material for sulfur and iodine (cathodes for lithium batteries). Open-capsular MOF can also be upgraded to a capsular carbon-based network, which exhibits efficient multifunctional electrocatalysis for oxygen evolution, hydrogen evolution, and oxygen reduction, achieving well-qualified assemblies of an overall water splitting and a rechargeable Zn–air battery, which affords remarkably practical prospects over previously reported electrocatalysts. The open-capsule nanostructures have been demonstrated to be vastly beneficial for easily loading I2 and S into an MOF capsule and full exposure of the inner surfaces during catalysis with the carbon-based capsule, which could greatly endow microcapsules with better performance than traditional nonhollow nanomaterials including nanosized MOFs and sheetlike crystals. Considering the rich diversities of the reported ligands and MOFs with open metal sites, our strategy will be broadly applicable for design and construction of various novel MOF capsules. The synthetic strategies also point out a new way for preparing hierarchical carbon-based nanostructures with adjustable morphologies and compositions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a new single-crystal capsular-MOF with openings on the wall is carefully designed at the molecular level and constructed from a rare crystal-structure transformation from a well-known three-dimensional MOF for the first time. Interestingly, the open-capsular MOF can be used as a nanoscale storage material for sulfur and iodine (cathodes for lithium batteries). Open-capsular MOF can also be upgraded to a capsular carbon-based network, which exhibits efficient multifunctional electrocatalysis for oxygen evolution, hydrogen evolution, and oxygen reduction, achieving well-qualified assemblies of an overall water splitting and a rechargeable Zn-air battery, which affords remarkably practical prospects over previously reported electrocatalysts. The open-capsule nanostructures have been demonstrated to be vastly beneficial for easily loading I2 and S into an MOF capsule and full exposure of the inner surfaces during catalysis with the carbon-based capsule, which could greatly endow microcapsules with better performance than traditional nonhollow nanomaterials including nanosized MOFs and sheetlike crystals. Considering the rich diversities of the reported ligands and MOFs with open metal sites, our strategy will be broadly applicable for design and construction of various novel MOF capsules. The synthetic strategies also point out a new way for preparing hierarchical carbon-based nanostructures with adjustable morphologies and compositions.

Experimental Section

Synthesis of FeNi-MIL-88B

A mixture of iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3⋅6H2O, 3.6 g, 13.3 mmol), nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 2.0 g, 6.7 mmol), and 2-aminoterephthalic acid (H2bdc-NH2, 3.6 g, 20 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (200 mL) and sonicated for 20 min. Subsequently, aqueous sodium hydroxide solution (8 mL, 1 M) was dropwise added into the above solution under stirring. The resulted solution was sonicated for 40 min and then transferred into a 500 mL vial sealed with a screw cap. The mixture was heated at 100 °C for 12 h. After that, brown solid was collected by centrifuge and washed by DMF and methanol (MeOH) several times. The obtained sample was dried in the air at room temperature overnight (yield 4.2 g, ~80%). Large single crystals for Fe-MIL-88B: a mixture of FeCl3⋅6H2O (2.7 g, 10 mmol), H2bdc-NH2 (1.8 g, 10mmol), hydrofluoric acid (3 mL), and DMF (100 mL) was stirred for 30min, transferred, and sealed into a 500 mL vial with a screw cap, which was heated at 100 °C for 3 days, finally giving orange crystals of Fe-MIL-88B ([Fe3(μ3-O)(bdc-NH2)3X(H2O)2], X = OH-/Cl-/F-).

Iodine Vapor Adsorption

Degassed MOF crystals (50 mg) in a small beaker and iodine (1.5 g) were placed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and then transferred into an oven heated at 100 °C for 2.5 h. After that, the obtained samples were collected and analyzed by TG.

elements.content: SCXRD measurements were carried out using a Rigaku AFC10 diffractometer with a Rigaku PILATUS 200 K system equipped with a MicroMax-007 HF/Varimax rotating-anode X-ray generator with confocal monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Crystal structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full matrix least-squares refinement using SHELXTL-2013 package. Fourier difference maps (F 0 – F c) were computed with the WinGX program system. Detailed structure refinement parameters and crystallographic data are given in Table S4.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction and Structure Analysis

SCXRD measurements were carried out using a Rigaku AFC10 diffractometer with a Rigaku PILATUS 200 K system equipped with a MicroMax-007 HF/Varimax rotating-anode X-ray generator with confocal monochromated Mo Kα radiation. Crystal structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full matrix least-squares refinement using SHELXTL-2013 package. Fourier difference maps (F 0 - F c) were computed with the WinGX program system. Detailed structure refinement parameters and crystallographic data are given in Table S4.

elements.content: The rechargeable Zn–air battery test was conducted in a home-built electrochemical cell where FeNiP/NCH catalysts were loaded on Ni foam (1 mg cm–2) as the air cathode and Zn plate as anode in 6.0 M KOH. For the rechargeable zinc–air batteries, 6.0 M KOH and 0.2 M ZnCl2 were employed as the electrolyte to ensure reversible Zn electrochemical reactions at the Zn plate. During discharge–charge cycling tests, the electrolyte was replenished once a day. Measurements were carried out at room temperature with a CHI 708EY electrochemical workstation and a Hokuto Denko HJ1001SD8C charge–discharge testing system.
elements.clean_text:
Fabrication of a Zn-Air Battery

The rechargeable Zn-air battery test was conducted in a home-built electrochemical cell where FeNiP/NCH catalysts were loaded on Ni foam (1 mg cm-2) as the air cathode and Zn plate as anode in 6.0 M KOH. For the rechargeable zinc-air batteries, 6.0 M KOH and 0.2 M ZnCl2 were employed as the electrolyte to ensure reversible Zn electrochemical reactions at the Zn plate. During discharge-charge cycling tests, the electrolyte was replenished once a day. Measurements were carried out at room temperature with a CHI 708EY electrochemical workstation and a Hokuto Denko HJ1001SD8C charge-discharge testing system.

cln_elements.content:
Recently, MOF-derived carbon composites, possessing excellent chemical stabilities and conductivities, have shown great potential applications in energy storage and conversion. However, nonhollow MOF-derived nanocomposites usually exhibit complete microporosity and undesired aggregation of metal-based nanoparticles, which are considered unfavorable for ion and electron transport. On the basis of these concerns, hollow architectures have recently emerged as an effective platform to significantly improve catalytic efficiency of metal nanocomposites because their shell nanostructures can endow materials with a higher density of surface-exposed active sites. More importantly, compared with those widely reported nonhollow MOF crystal-derived hollow carbons, directly using hollow MOF crystals as precursors can effectively reduce the aggregation of metal active sites during pyrolysis, although harsh annealing usually causes a partial or even complete collapse of MOF morphologies. Fortunately, through pyrolysis–phosphidation with melamine, capsular-MOF successfully evolved into a capsular carbon embedded with iron–nickel phosphide nanoparticles ( and S33). For comparison, FeNiP/NCS from solid (nonhollow)-MOF and FeNiP/C from FeNi-MIL-88B were also prepared. PXRD of FeNiP/NCH shows a weak peak located at 26.4° assigned to the (002) plane of graphitic carbon (b), which is further verified by the IR and Raman spectra with a G-band at 1586 cm–1 (Figure S34). Besides, the D-band of Raman spectra at 1355 cm–1 manifests the presence of a disordered/defect carbon. Additionally, other peaks appearing at 32.2, 36.8, 48.0, and 56.1° can be indexed to (−202), (021), (220), and (310) planes of NiP2, and peaks at 31.2, 35.2, 40.2, 44.1, and 47.6° refer to (101), (200), (111), (201), and (210) planes of Fe2P, respectively. Remarkably, all of the diffraction peaks are significantly broadened, which might be due to ultrafine sizes of NiP2 and Fe2P nanoparticles confirmed by subsequent TEM and SAED measurements. However, for FeNiP/C and FeNiP/NCS, these peaks become more sharp, and nonphosphatized Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloys (PDF no. 47-1405) are obviously observed (Figure S35). SEM and TEM images demonstrate that FeNiP/NCH retains capsular morphology with larger openings compared with capsular-MOF (c,d). As a secondary nitrogen and carbon source, coexistence of melamine results in the growth of numerous carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on the surface of capsular carbons, which are successfully connected with each other to form networks (Figures S36 and S37). HRTEM, SAED, and HAADF-STEM images and elemental maps of FeNiP/NCH (f, S37, and S38) reveal that Fe, Ni, and P elements are uniformly distributed over the entire capsule. Obviously, by virtue of spatially homogeneous separation of Fe­(III) and Ni­(II) ions in the thin walls of precursor capsular nanocrystals, the NiP2 and Fe2P nanoparticles are homogeneously distributed over the entire capsule nanostructures with extremely small sizes. Compared with FeNiP/NCH, as suggested by PXRD and SAED, besides larger nanoparticles of NiP2 and Fe2P, Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloy is found in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C (Figures S39–S43), which can be possibly attributed to the partial phosphorization of large nanoparticles of Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloy in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C. Their chemical status and elemental composition are further studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) analysis. A survey scan of FeNiP/NCH reveals the presence of C, O, N, P, Fe, and Ni (Figure S44). The high-resolution spectrum of N 1s can be divided into three peaks at 400.9, 399.9, and 398.7 eV, corresponding to graphitic, pyrrolic, and pyridinic-N, respectively. Significantly, the signal peak of P 2p (133.5 eV) can be definitely detected, and similar results are obtained in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C, demonstrating their successful phosphorization (Figure S45). Notably, only in XPS of FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C, signal peaks of metallic Fe 2p3/2 (707.0 eV) and Ni 2p3/2 (852.7 eV) can be detected (Figure S46), in good agreement with PXRD, HRTEM, and SAED. N2 sorption measurements reveal that FeNiP/NCH shows a high BET surface area of 142 m2·g–1 and pore volume of 0.549 cm3·g–1, larger than those of FeNiP/NCS (118 m2·g–1, 0.367 cm3·g–1) and FeNiP/C (79 m2·g–1, 0.226 cm3·g–1) (Figure S47a and Table S2). Pore size distribution curves (Figure S47b) illustrate that FeNiP/NCH possesses obviously mesoporous structures (∼10 nm). Moreover, as also suggested by TEM (d, S37, S41, and S42), FeNiP/NCH, FeNiP/NCS, and FeNiP/C have rich macropores. These unique hierarchical pores will be significantly beneficial to mass and charge transport for electrocatalysis.

Hydrogen Evolution and Overall Water Splitting

Motivated by the outstanding OER performance of FeNiP/NCH, electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) was also investigated. Distinctly, FeNiP/NCH obtains 10 mA cm–2 at a small overpotential of 216 mV, which is superior to the FeNiP/C (258 mV) and FeNiP/NCS (315 mV) catalysts. The corresponding Tafel slope of the FeNiP/NCH catalyst (125 mV dec–1) is also smaller than those of FeNiP/C (144 mV dec–1), FeNiP/NCS (177 mV dec–1) (a), and many other reported bifunctional catalysts (Table S11), revealing more favorable electrocatalytic kinetics on the FeNiP/NCH catalyst for HER. It should be noted that the Tafel slope of FeNiP/NCH catalyst (125 mV dec–1) suggests that its HER process undergoes a Volmer–Heyrovesky pathway. Notably, LSV scanning for 5000 cycles and long-term chronoamperometry (>68 h) measurements demonstrate its good stability during HER (Figures S55 and S56). Moreover, the structure and chemical components of FeNiP/NCH can be preserved very well after HER tests (Figures S57 and S58). Considering the electrocatalytic activities of FeNiP/NCH for HER and OER with excellent stabilities, an electrolyzer was assembled using FeNiP/NCH as both cathode and anode for overall water splitting. As revealed in LSV (b and S59), FeNiP/NCH exhibits outstanding splitting performance with a small cell voltage of 1.59 and 1.91 V to achieve 10 and 100 mA cm–2, respectively, superior to those of many reported non-noble-metal electrocatalysts (Table S12). In addition, the water electrolyzer durability was well confirmed by carrying out the reaction at different current densities from 10 to 100 mA cm–2 for over 40 h (c and S60), proving the prominent stability of FeNiP/NCH catalyst for overall water splitting.

Besides, the D-band of Raman spectra at 1355 cm-1 manifests the presence of a disordered/defect carbon. Additionally, other peaks appearing at 32.2, 36.8, 48.0, and 56.1° can be indexed to (-202), (021), (220), and (310) planes of NiP2, and peaks at 31.2, 35.2, 40.2, 44.1, and 47.6° refer to (101), (200), (111), (201), and (210) planes of Fe2P, respectively. Remarkably, all of the diffraction peaks are significantly broadened, which might be due to ultrafine sizes of NiP2 and Fe2P nanoparticles confirmed by subsequent TEM and SAED measurements. However, for FeNiP/C and FeNiP/NCS, these peaks become more sharp, and nonphosphatized Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloys (PDF no. 47-1405) are obviously observed (Figure S35). SEM and TEM images demonstrate that FeNiP/NCH retains capsular morphology with larger openings compared with capsular-MOF (c,d). As a secondary nitrogen and carbon source, coexistence of melamine results in the growth of numerous carbon nanotubes (CNTs) on the surface of capsular carbons, which are successfully connected with each other to form networks (Figures S36 and S37). HRTEM, SAED, and HAADF-STEM images and elemental maps of FeNiP/NCH (f, S37, and S38) reveal that Fe, Ni, and P elements are uniformly distributed over the entire capsule. Obviously, by virtue of spatially homogeneous separation of Fe(III) and Ni(II) ions in the thin walls of precursor capsular nanocrystals, the NiP2 and Fe2P nanoparticles are homogeneously distributed over the entire capsule nanostructures with extremely small sizes. Compared with FeNiP/NCH, as suggested by PXRD and SAED, besides larger nanoparticles of NiP2 and Fe2P, Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloy is found in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C (Figures S39-S43), which can be possibly attributed to the partial phosphorization of large nanoparticles of Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloy in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C. Their chemical status and elemental composition are further studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) analysis. A survey scan of FeNiP/NCH reveals the presence of C, O, N, P, Fe, and Ni (Figure S44). The high-resolution spectrum of N 1s can be divided into three peaks at 400.9, 399.9, and 398.7 eV, corresponding to graphitic, pyrrolic, and pyridinic-N, respectively. Significantly, the signal peak of P 2p (133.5 eV) can be definitely detected, and similar results are obtained in FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C, demonstrating their successful phosphorization (Figure S45). Notably, only in XPS of FeNiP/NCS and FeNiP/C, signal peaks of metallic Fe 2p3/2 (707.0 eV) and Ni 2p3/2 (852.7 eV) can be detected (Figure S46), in good agreement with PXRD, HRTEM, and SAED. N2 sorption measurements reveal that FeNiP/NCH shows a high BET surface area of 142 m2⋅g-1 and pore volume of 0.549 cm3⋅g-1, larger than those of FeNiP/NCS (118 m2⋅g-1, 0.367 cm3⋅g-1) and FeNiP/C (79 m2⋅g-1, 0.226 cm3⋅g-1) (Figure S47a and Table S2). Pore size distribution curves (Figure S47b) illustrate that FeNiP/NCH possesses obviously mesoporous structures (~10 nm). Moreover, as also suggested by TEM (d, S37, S41, and S42), FeNiP/NCH, FeNiP/NCS, and FeNiP/C have rich macropores. These unique hierarchical pores will be significantly beneficial to mass and charge transport for electrocatalysis.

Hydrogen Evolution and Overall Water Splitting

Motivated by the outstanding OER performance of FeNiP/NCH, electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) was also investigated. Distinctly, FeNiP/NCH obtains 10 mA cm-2 at a small overpotential of 216 mV, which is superior to the FeNiP/C (258 mV) and FeNiP/NCS (315 mV) catalysts. The corresponding Tafel slope of the FeNiP/NCH catalyst (125 mV dec-1) is also smaller than those of FeNiP/C (144 mV dec-1), FeNiP/NCS (177 mV dec-1) (a), and many other reported bifunctional catalysts (Table S11), revealing more favorable electrocatalytic kinetics on the FeNiP/NCH catalyst for HER. It should be noted that the Tafel slope of FeNiP/NCH catalyst (125 mV dec-1) suggests that its HER process undergoes a Volmer-Heyrovesky pathway. Notably, LSV scanning for 5000 cycles and long-term chronoamperometry (>68 h) measurements demonstrate its good stability during HER (Figures S55 and S56). Moreover, the structure and chemical components of FeNiP/NCH can be preserved very well after HER tests (Figures S57 and S58). Considering the electrocatalytic activities of FeNiP/NCH for HER and OER with excellent stabilities, an electrolyzer was assembled using FeNiP/NCH as both cathode and anode for overall water splitting. As revealed in LSV (b and S59), FeNiP/NCH exhibits outstanding splitting performance with a small cell voltage of 1.59 and 1.91 V to achieve 10 and 100 mA cm-2, respectively, superior to those of many reported non-noble-metal electrocatalysts (Table S12). In addition, the water electrolyzer durability was well confirmed by carrying out the reaction at different current densities from 10 to 100 mA cm-2 for over 40 h (c and S60), proving the prominent stability of FeNiP/NCH catalyst for overall water splitting.
